text: hi everyone anthony cartano here the
internet's busiest music nerd and it's
time for a review of this new kenny
beats project louis this is a new solo
instrumental album from the one and only
kenneth of the beats aka kenny beatz a
well-known producer and
multi-instrumentalist who we have talked
about on the channel quite a bit mostly
in the context of music he's produced
for other artists to rap or sing on but
it's also important to note that kenny
beats is not just a musician he's also a
streamer a persona an icon a multi-level
marketing genius who's put himself out
there more effectively than any man
breaking out making beats over the past
10 years so it's interesting that now we
are getting a project where kenny beets
and his producer chops are truly the
stars of the show for 17 tracks and 33
minutes and if kenny does anything
impressively on this project it is
provide range the rhythms across this
record aren't too loose or technical or
flashy anything like that very punchy
very direct nothing too crazy in terms
of surreal or psychedelic sound play on
these cuts too but there is a consistent
cleanliness to the production on this
project every piece of instrumentation
is flawlessly assembled placed very
carefully and methodically and as i said
across the 17 tracks here kenny covers a
lot of bases like with the track hooper
which in my opinion is one of the best
and bassiest trap reggae fusions i've
heard the beat is tight as hell and the
w hypnotic horn samples as well as
keyboard embellishments are a nice touch
and of course this track like many here
segues flawlessly into the next one in
this case that is the song still which
is one of a few cuts on this record that
features some guest vocals you can also
catch slow tie for example on the very
intoxicating family tree but with hooper
we get some additional vocals from jpeg
mafia and nothing in terms of like a
formal or fully fleshed out verse
nothing like that what we're hearing
sounds like snippets of work peggy has
done with kenny that's just kind of you
know just cutting room floor stuff and
kenny is effectively chopping this up
into bits and using it as seasoning for
the instrumental which is great it does
give the track a bit of punch but the
star of the show truly is this bass line
and these gorgeous layered vocal
harmonies and that's kind of the thing
with each track on this project kenny
brings together a solid beat and then
forges sculpts or samples a very
specific musical idea to focus on and
pair with it while also trying to find
subtle ways to build on this idea across
the runtime of the track for a minute or
two and for an instrumental tapestry
such as this what more could you want
like the busy choppy little woodwind
harmonies bubbling up all over moir plus
the various sound effects and key
embellishments that orbit them are great
there's also the beautiful eternal where
there's certainly an infinite quality to
the groovy bass and drum loops they're
paired with these distant croons that
are a little pitched and crying out
about living forever a touching
sentiment considering the impetus for
this project was kenny's father being
diagnosed with cancer which makes the
sentiment coming out of the sampled
lyrics on last words hit even harder too
as well as the heartwarming father-son
interactions on the intro track as well
as the perch this lp isn't all
sentimental nostalgia though there are
lots of fun bops to be had on this
project too like on drop 10 for example
where we hear some dilla esque magic on
a perfectly funky soul flip that
undergoes a few different phases under
90 seconds those cute glockenspiel notes
the trippy synth delays the hook just a
miss just a misdemeanor hit it that time
and also that dreamy outro is wonderful
too there's a similar era of music being
pulled from on the song really really as
well and one of the many cool things
about this track is how seamlessly kenny
is able to pull together
the instrumentation or the ideas that he
is sampling but also the original or
live instrumentation he's bringing to
the table the final result is just
really cohesive we also have some really
impressive guitar work on the song
rotten and on the closing track hot hand
this is one of a few songs on the record
where
kenny proves that he's not just you know
some beat maker but he also uh does
really well at arranging the mystical
arpeggios on this track and what sounds
like some fretless bass lines are really
beautiful and enchanting and all the
acoustic chaos that builds on top of it
progressively toward the end is quite
the feet also make note of the way the
laid back rhythms and virtuoso synth
leads keys strings and horns come
together on parentheses we also have the
cheeky held my head as well as the fiery
beats and horn sections on so they say
without a doubt this project starts as
strong as it finishes and there were
only a few cuts on this thing that
didn't completely do it for me the
guitar licks and vocal samples on get
around for example i think come together
a bit too sloppily and the lazy jazz
wrap solos and grooves on that third
thing while they are nice while they're
on i think they could have been pushed a
little further to bring a bit more heat
but with that being said this is a
really great solid instrumental project
from kenny beatz truly his contribution
to the long lineage of records dropped
by a multitude of talented
beat smiths out there in the vein of a j
dilla record or an introducing if this
is kenny beats defining himself in that
way i would say he's doing a pretty damn
good job at it maybe he doesn't exactly
forge a trademark sound on this record
in the way that those albums did but he
does show his production chops are not
to be [ __ ] with and that he's
certainly a musical chameleon kind of a
jack of all trades in a way truly doing
it all and doing it all really well and
for sure some of these beats some of
these loops and some of these melodies
he has conjured here are gonna be
sticking in my head for a while feeling
a decent two strong eight on this one
tran position have you given this record
a listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
is another video that you can check out
hit that up or the link to subscribe to
the channel anthony fantano kenny beatz
forever
